item.title: He never promised us a rose garden – but Keir Starmer’s ‘doom and gloom’ speech was partisan finger pointing
item.description: The prime minister is preparing the ground for a difficult budget but blaming his predecessors will only get him so far.

item.title: Stranded Boeing Starliner astronauts to stay six more months in space – what this means for the future of commercial spaceflight
item.description: Nasa’s decision to prioritise the safety of the astronauts, and to work with another commercial partner in finding a solution, is a triumph of wisdom and caution.

item.title: Ukraine recap: drone warfare brings new phase to battlefront
item.description: The latest round-up of news from Ukraine.

item.title: Why seagulls don’t want your chips as much as you might think
item.description: Seagulls have an innate preference for fish and mussels rather than your chips, research shows.

item.title: Qantas mistakenly sold first-class tickets for bargain prices. Here’s why it made sense for the airline not to honour the deal in full
item.description: Qantas sought to keep all passengers happy and on-side, while not costing the airline a fortune.

item.title: How Democrats are using music to reclaim ‘Republican values’ of freedom, patriotism and leadership
item.description: Carefully chosen music encourages a sense of unity, sending important messages to the wider electorate that reinforce and differentiate the identity and values of the party and its leaders.

item.title: Connection with coast and inland waterways has multiple health benefits – here’s how we measure them
item.description: Looking at, listening to, and immersing ourselves in inland and coastal waters can directly benefit our physical and mental health - here’s how the study of blue health has evolved.

item.title: We’ve unlocked exotic new beer flavours using genetics
item.description: Until a few years ago, it was impossible to create new lager beer.

item.title: Has a new royal order in Saudi Arabia revealed the future line of succession?
item.description: We may have taken a step towards knowing who the Saudi Kingdom’s third-most powerful person is.

item.title: Tell us about the play that changed your life
item.description: We would like to hear about your momentous theatrical discoveries

item.title: The Cable’s campaign succeeds: more than 50% increase in membership income and a £40k bonus
item.description: The support of our many new, and existing, members has seen the Cable pass the membership target we’ve been working towards for a year, a week ahead of the deadline.

item.title: Huw Montague Rendall: Contemplation album review – young opera star justifies the buzz
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Montague Rendall/Opéra Orchestre Normandie Rouen/Glassberg<!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Erato)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->The debut album from the British baritone lives up to the hype, showcasing his velvet and nuanced singing with room to spare

item.title: Jason Schwartzman: ‘I was the kid driving around all the record stores buying all the Oasis singles’
item.description: The actor answers your questions on auditioning for Wes Anderson, his love of Britpop, his telepathic mother and never hearing back from Ringo Starr

item.title: Jon Hopkins: Ritual review | Alexis Petridis’s album of the week
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Domino)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->Originally written for an installation with mind-altering intentions, the producer’s seventh album is occasionally engaging but dissolves into drift

item.title: The Smile Detail Third Studio Album, ‘Cutouts’
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> It includes string arrangements by the London Contemporary Orchestra

item.title: Making homes ready for net zero depends heavily on people’s understanding and habits
item.description: We interviewed people living in new net-zero homes to see what the construction industry could learn.

item.title: More children are getting ACL injuries – here’s what could be done to prevent them
item.description: The anterior cruciate ligament is crucial in movements such as pivoting and making jump landings.

item.title: Conscription laws passed during the US civil war offered exemptions – are there lessons for Ukraine today?
item.description: Historically allowing opt outs of conscription has created tension in the population.

item.title: Slave Play: how policing audience phones during nude scene affects the meaning of the production
item.description: If policing the audience during the play is necessary, perhaps the casting or the nudity needs reconsidering, otherwise both simply read as gimmicks.

item.title: Félicia Atkinson to Release New Album, ‘Space As An Instrument’
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> It’s forthcoming on Shelter Press, the label she co-runs

item.title: Darkness, drama and Daft Punk: the Weeknd’s best songs – ranked!
item.description: Ahead of Abel Tesfaye’s livestreamed concert in Brazil to launch his new era, we rate his path from cult mixtape star to pop icon

item.title: Geoengineering: the scientists who argue modifying the climate could buy the world time – podcast
item.description: In the first of two episodes on geoengineering, The Conversation Weekly examines the case for repairing the climate with technological interventions.

item.title: How drone attacks are changing the rules and the costs of the Ukraine war
item.description: Drone warfare has been highly significant in the Ukraine war, and now it is entering a new phase.

item.title: I’m an expert in ancient Greece – Netflix’s Kaos is the cleverest retelling of Greek mythology I’ve ever seen
item.description: Kaos is a thrilling romp about gods and mortals vying for power and influence over the cosmos.

item.title: ‘We need to face them on the streets’: how trade unions are responding to the far-right threat
item.description: The scale of the recent far-right turnout in Bristol rattled many trade unionists. Now, an anti-racist taskforce is forming to organise opposition in the South West, but activists say unions must show they have migrant workers’ backs.

item.title: Oasisters: Meet Liam & Noel’s 21st Century Female Fan Army
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> On the anniversary of Definitely Maybe and news of comeback gigs, author Anna Doble, speaks to a new generation of young women who are getting ready to show the world that Oasis belong to them. Main picture: a selfie by Bella Perozzi

item.title: The Labels Shaping a New Ukrainian Underground Part 2: Money, Money, Money…
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> In the latest edition of New Voices Ukraine, tQ’s new collaboration with 20ft Radio, Neformat, the British Council and Ukrainian Institute, Yaryna Denysyuk of Neformat, Yaryna Denysyuk continues her look into Ukrainian DIY record labels. Having surveyed those attempting utopian collective approaches in part one, this time she examines the unavoidable downsides of running a label during wartime

item.title: Practical Magic: The Self-Titled Debut by Tristwch Y Fenywod
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> Featuring members of Guttersnipe, Hawthonn, and Slaylor Moon, Tristwch Y Fenywod spin wild, esoteric fables (with just a touch of disco)

item.title: The Soundcarriers – Through Other Reflections
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> The Soundcarriers

item.title: The new climate stripes? How creativity can inspire environmental action
item.description: A set of graphics showing how air pollution has changed in cities around the world hopes to capitalise on the ability of striking visuals to motivate people.

item.title: DNA reveals secrets of cave-dwelling medieval community that survived conquest and epidemics
item.description: It’s unclear why people chose to live in the caves, but DNA is shedding light on their lives.

item.title: Middle-class British people are talking more alike than ever
item.description: The rise of corporate inclusivity might be responsible.

item.title: Oasis: expert explains the formula for a successful band reunion – and why some crash and burn
item.description: Since there have been bands, bands have been breaking up. And since bands have been breaking up, bands have been reforming.

item.title: How the Republicans are trying to use Trump’s revised court charges to energise the campaign
item.description: Donald Trump may try and use the news of his court case charges to grab more television air time, and shift the energy of his campaign.

item.title: Jackson Hole: how a meeting of bankers in a remote Wyoming valley could have consequences for us all
item.description: The annual symposium brought the world’s central bankers together in Wyoming.

item.title: Keir Starmer’s national security adviser controversy explained
item.description: Gwyn Jenkins will not be the new prime minister’s adviser but that’s not unexpected under a change of government.

item.title: The Taliban’s harsh new ‘vice and virtue’ laws are a throwback to the oppression of the 1990s – especially for the women of Afghanistan
item.description: Three years ago the Taliban promised it had changed. It is now clear that it hasn’t.

item.title: Michael Mosley’s final series: how we showed what happens to your body when you’re stressed
item.description: And what you can do about it.

item.title: Caribou Unveils New Album, ‘Honey’
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> Dan Snaith is back with his first full-length under the moniker since 2021

item.title: Godspeed You! Black Emperor Reveal New Album, ‘No Title As Of 13 February 2024 28,340 Dead’
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> The Canadian group’s new record is split across six tracks

item.title: Kim Deal Details Debut Solo LP, ‘Nobody Loves You More’
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> 4AD will release the 11-track record in November

item.title: Young British people: have you worked seasonal jobs in mainland Europe in recent summers?
item.description: We would like to hear from young British people under 25 about what the opportunities for working in mainland Europe’s tourism and hospitality industries are like

item.title: Tell us: how will you be affected by the state-funded childcare expansion in England?
item.description: We’d like to hear from parents, early years practitioners, childminders and council workers on the expansion of “free” childcare for all children from the age of nine months

item.title: Vladimir, vapes and defending democracy: when the Cable met Pussy Riot in BS3
item.description: Celebrating the subversive, we spent an evening with the legendary Russian dissidents to get behind the balaclavas to discuss all things protest.

item.title: Most food waste happens at home – new research reveals the best ways to reduce it
item.description: Most food waste happens at home - new research reveals the most effective ways to encourage people to reduce it.

item.title: Ritual, Hypnosis and Drone: Richard Norris’ Favourite Albums
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> With both The Grid and Beyond The Wizard’s Sleeve back in action, and new memoir Strange Things Are Happening out now, Richard Norris takes Patrick Clarke through an eclectic 13 records that have defined his life in music

item.title: Endon – Fall Of Spring
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> Endon

item.title: The Art Of Falling Apart: Considering The Usefulness Of Fallibility At Mutek 2024
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> Dan Dylan Wray watches Factory Floor, Marie Davidson and Colin Stetson at MUTEK, and considers the importance of fallibility in electronic music under the monolithic shadow of AI. Amnesia Scanner & Freeka Tet photograph by Vivien Gaumand

item.title: The Quietus International: Portuguese Music Reviewed by Pedro João Santos
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> In the second instalment of our journey through the global underground, Pedro João Santos delivers a guide to the bold musicians, daring festivals and crucial grassroots collectives that are defining DIY music in Portugal in an era of increasing gentrification, and picks out five key releases

item.title: Council still hounding people with bailiffs after ‘ethical’ approach promise
item.description: The Cable has uncovered evidence Bristol City Council is referring thousands of council tax debts to enforcement agencies despite a stated policy to do so only as a last resort.

item.title: PlayThatBoiZay – VIP
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> PlayThatBoiZay

item.title: ‘I’ve waited 25 years for this moment’: Oasis, the reunion – and what made them great
item.description: Their sneering vocals, seething guitars and thermonuclear charisma electrified the 90s. But will a reunion be a Champagne Supernova – or a Digsy’s Dinner? Our music writers weigh in

item.title: Will an Oasis reunion be a success? Definitely. Will it be worth it? Maybe | Alexis Petridis
item.description: Their first two albums and B-sides were fantastic, but after that things got bloated and weary. The reunion could go either way and that’s what makes it exciting

item.title: ‘You should be partying when you write party music’: pop hedonists Confidence Man on their super-sweaty new album
item.description: They want to hurl cash over their audiences, fire lasers, and make pantomime horses sexy. But, the Australian band say, there’s a dark side to their DayGlo dance-pop

item.title: All for you! Janet Jackson, Snõõper, Bob Dylan and more: the best music of autumn 2024
item.description: From Chat Pile’s apocalyptic noise to Nala Sinephro’s celestial bliss, plus posthumous releases from MC5 and Sophie, here are the albums and tours not to miss – while in classical, Kahchun Wong takes over at the Hallé

item.title: Gumbo Ya-Ya: David Toop on Dr John’s Gris-gris
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->In an exclusive extract from his new book, Two-Headed Doctor, David Toop recalls the first time he heard the weird and wonderful debut album by the American singer-songwriter

item.title: Nuala Kennedy and Eamon O’Leary: Hydra review – sumptuous folk songs
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Under the Arch)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->With guests including Will Oldham and Anaïs Mitchell, this record’s island setting seems to bring extra light and warmth to stories of the sea, love, work, war and migration

item.title: Spirit of the Beehive: You’ll Have to Lose Something review – like an arthouse horror movie in sound
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Saddle Creek)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->Disruptive, disorienting and disturbing, the trio are still making creative leaps on their fifth album, mixing up slacker indie with strange beats and plenty of screaming

item.title: Kamala Harris accepts Democratic nomination, urges Americans to 'fight for this country' – video
item.description: US vice-president and Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris took to the stage on the final day of the Democratic national convention in Chicago, delivering the biggest speech of her political career. With less than three months left before election day - and with polls showing a tight contest against the Republican former president Donald Trump - Harris fired up the Democratic faithful by reflecting on her upbringing and past as a California attorney-general, asking the audience to ‘imagine Trump with no guardrails’, and calling on Americans to ‘fight for this country we love’

item.title: ‘I’m a tyrant!’: pop superstar Sabrina Carpenter on freakish fame, fighting Disney and writing the song of the summer
item.description: After 14 years in obscurity, she has now been streamed by billions, censored by the BBC and toured with Taylor Swift – and she’s still only 25. But the Espresso singer says the public aren’t making life easy

item.title: What Ukraine's incursion into Russia means for the war – video explainer
item.description: Ukraine has made incursions into Russian territory, boosting morale and changing the dynamic of the two-year war that began after Russia’s 2022 full-scale invasion.

item.title: ‘Optimists have happier lives’: Laurie Anderson on Bowie, Lou Reed and ‘romantic, inspiring’ JFK
item.description: Releasing a new album inspired by Amelia Earhart, the US musician answers your questions about her letters to Kennedy, wrestling Andy Kaufman and ​performing for thousands of dogs at Sydney Opera House

item.title: Smetana & Schubert: Piano Trios album review – immensely promising debut
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Trio Bohémo<!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Supraphon)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->The Czech trio deliver two great works with freshness, energy and maximum intensity

item.title: Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds: Wild God review – this masterpiece will make you fall back in love with life
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Pias)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->Contemplating pain, death and suffering, rock’s former prince of darkness finds euphoria despite it all, on an album of contagious joy and thrilling melody

item.title: Education is the great liberator: the Bristol activists forging links with teachers in Palestine
item.description: Yasmeen Eshtaya is a Palestinian teacher whose life has been deeply affected by the brutal violence of the Israeli state. But she is committed to reconciliation and forming bonds through teaching Arabic – including to people in Bristol.

item.title: Kneecap review – Irish-language hip-hop trio in fiercely riotous Belfast romp
item.description: The story of Northern Irish teenagers who reinvent the political purpose of hip-hop, the film is most uproarious when the energy of the music lets loose

item.title: Under surveillance: how a man was recalled to prison after visiting a Bristol anarchist social centre
item.description: Toby Shone’s arrest by counter-terrorism police surveilling the BASE centre in Easton shows the state’s escalating clampdown on political dissent.

item.title: Fed up with the failings of mainstream media? Stand to be a Cable director
item.description: The Bristol Cable is looking for people to join our board of directors, who support and scrutinise the staff team’s work.

item.title: 2024 AGM: Help shape the Cable’s future and hear from inside our latest campaign to end Section 60
item.description: The Bristol Cable is not your average newspaper: we get together with members of the coop to plan ahead.

item.title: Listen: People Just Do Something and how to start a student encampment
item.description: People Just Do Something is a relaxing and possibly enraging podcast about people who might self-identify as activists, untangling the means of effecting change in Bristol, broken Britain and beyond.

item.title: New radical plans tabled to remove cars from Bristol city centre
item.description: Proposals to pedestrianise parts of the city centre and give buses more priority that were first developed under Labour are now being consulted on by the new Green-led council.

item.title: ‘Bristol can lead the way in pushing for legalising cannabis’
item.description: Cannabis is now legally regulated in a growing number of countries around the world, but the UK is being left behind.

item.title: Listen: The Debrief: No far right in sight… Bristol’s victory over hatred
item.description: Join Cable journalists discussing what’s driving the far-right violence across the country, and our city’s incredible show of solidarity as thousands took to the streets to say no to racist, xenophobic hatred.

item.title: Leaseholders are calling for feudal system to be abolished, but what will Labour actually change?
item.description: Change is on the horizon for leaseholders in Bristol now that Labour is in power. But it can’t come soon enough.

item.title: The Cable View: The right-wing press peddling hateful, racist bullshit has fuelled the violence on our streets. It’s time for change.
item.description: When sensationalist drivel is favoured over accurate, balanced, nuanced and insightful journalism, we all lose out.

item.title: Foodies’ favourite: the Italian tipple beloved by in-the-know chefs and bar staff
item.description: With its complex flavour and long Italian history, it’s no wonder the food world loves Fernet-Branca

item.title: Salute! Three of the best bars to enjoy Italian cocktails in the UK
item.description: From Edinburgh to London, embrace the sophistication of an aperitivo at these stylish watering holes

item.title: How to tap into ‘barcore’ – the new style trend causing a stir
item.description: Chef-based fashion has been bubbling up in restaurant kitchens for some time – and now there’s inspiration to be found in the world of bars too

item.title: 'Little Gaza’: Inside the fight for the West Bank
item.description: Across the West Bank, battles between the Israeli Defence Forces and various Palestinian factions have been going on for decades. The IDF began stepping up raids in mid 2022, but the violence in areas such as Jenin and Nablus has soared in the wake of Hamas’s rampage through Israel on October 7th.

item.title: Huge counter demo in Bristol sends clear message that far right not welcome – as it happened
item.description: After the Bristol riot on Saturday, Cable reporters were live at the scene as counter protesters returned to the streets to stand up to the far right.

item.title: Racist and traumatising: inside a Section 60 suspicionless stop and search operation
item.description: Officers searched innocent children, disproportionately targeted people of colour and undermined their anti-racism reforms during a 48-hour police operation in February. Their narrative that it was an effective knife-crime deterrent, done with consent, is misleading.

item.title: No To Section 60: Letter to local MPs demanding suspicionless search legislation is scrapped
item.description: Here’s a draft letter to be sent to your local MP demanding that they push for the repeal of Section 60 police stop and search powers

item.title: Long Read: Bristol took a stand against the far right, and it’s preparing to do it all over again
item.description: As the dust settles on the weekends’ clashes, the Cable reflects on the evening’s events - the racism, the resistance and the tensions that fuelled them.

item.title: Why is anti-immigration sentiment on the rise in Canada? – video
item.description: Canada has long been celebrated for its welcoming stance towards immigrants, fostering a prosperous, multicultural society. But in recent years, rising concerns over living costs and housing shortages have fueled a mounting scepticism of the country’s mass immigration policies. Leyland Cecco spends time in Toronto – a rapidly growing city where rent is up more than 40% in just two years – to understand the sharp shift in opinion

item.title: ‘Bristol’s council housing failings are shocking – but are just the tip of a massive national iceberg’
item.description: Decades of underinvestment in council homes by central government have led to unacceptable living standards for tenants, in our city and across the country. A national solution is needed.

item.title: Listen: People Just Do Something with Grace Blakeley and the ‘cacophony of woke’
item.description: People Just Do Something is a relaxing and possibly enraging podcast about people who might self-identify as activists, untangling the means of effecting change in Bristol, broken Britain and beyond.

item.title: Are the Greens going to save Yew Tree Farm?
item.description: Yew Tree Farm, one of Bristol’s most important wildlife sites, remains under threat from private and council development. But now the Greens say they don’t have the power to deliver on their commitment to protect it.

item.title: I'm under attack and fighting back: the scandal trapping carers - video
item.description: Debbie cares full-time for her elderly mother, works part-time as a cleaner, and claims carer’s allowance of £81.90 a week. But she was one of hundreds of thousands of carers to receive a demand from the Department for Work and Pensions to pay back large sums of money for inadvertently going slightly over the earnings limit. Now Debbie and carers like her are starting to fight back and demand change to the system

item.title: The car park kickabouts tackling anti-social behaviour in Hartcliffe
item.description: Football charity the Robins Foundation responded to reports of antisocial behaviour outside Hartcliffe’s Morrisons by organising football sessions in its car park. It’s led to a claimed 60% drop in complaints.

item.title: Mikaela Loach: ‘We need climate justice, not just climate action’
item.description: Climate activist and author Mikaela Loach spoke at a packed out live event earlier this summer about how she processed her climate guilt and how we can fight for a more just future.

item.title: Council forced to place vulnerable children into illegal homes because system is ‘broken’, says leader
item.description: Cllr Tony Dyer say the root cause was a lack of accommodation for vulnerable youngsters and that this needed to be fixed.

item.title: Early failures by council in Bristol Beacon revamp cost millions, report finds
item.description: The cost of refurbishing the iconic Bristol music venue almost tripled from £48million to £132million.

item.title: Listen: Cable Longreads – ‘Hollow victory’: a rape survivor’s journey through broken justice system
item.description: Cable reporter Priyanka Raval investigated whether the police’s new approach to prosecuting sexual violence is really making a difference to survivors.

item.title: ‘Collective power is where it’s at’: City Academy workers celebrate strike action successes
item.description: Union members at the east Bristol secondary school have achieved most of a series of asks from the academy trust that manages it, after announcing rolling walkouts. Workers say the action has brought staff together.

item.title: Cable Live x Bristol Transformed – can Apartheid-Free Zones help liberate Palestine?
item.description: The panel asks what was the St Paul’s Apartheid-Free Zone – and how can it be a model in today’s fight for Palestinian freedom?

item.title: Watchdog finds ‘serious failings’ after concluding council does not know what state its housing is in
item.description: Bristol City Council has been called out by a government regulator for not meeting new quality standards, with thousands of repairs and damp and mould cases long overdue for action and many safety check records missing.

item.title: VIDEO: Chief constable challenged on ‘anti-racist policing’ progress and stop and search reform
item.description: It’s been a year since Avon and Somerset’s chief constable Sarah Crew admitted her service was institutionally racist, but what is she actually doing about it?

item.title: ‘The only language the university speaks is money’: pro-Palestine students now facing eviction
item.description: A possession order brought by Bristol University to evict the protest camp has been rejected - but only until further hearings on 19 July.

item.title: Low turnout: why didn’t you vote at the general election?
item.description: 14 years of Tory rule came to an end last week, but turnout was the lowest in years, so we want to hear from people who didn’t vote.

item.title: Listen: the Debrief – raking over a historic set of Bristol general election results
item.description: Join sleep-deprived Cable journalists Priyanka Raval and Matty Edwards as they attempt to reflect on a long night of election fever that saw Bristol’s first Green MP elected – and senior Tories kicked out around the city’s edges.

item.title: Historic Bristol general election results see first ever Green MP and Tory wipeout
item.description: All seats in and around Bristol were won by Labour, except Bristol Central where the Greens romped to an impressive victory.

item.title: LIVE: Bristol general election results, as Greens win Bristol Central and Labour gains seats off Tories
item.description: Bristol general election results 2024: Labour will be looking to take seats off the Tories on the edge of Bristol in the general election, while the Greens have their eyes on Bristol Central.

item.title: VIDEO: What We Want – Meaningful climate action not culture wars
item.description: Extinction Rebellion activist Kathy says the Tory government’s disgraceful legacy of weaponising action on climate change as part of culture wars.

item.title: Sign up for the Guardian Documentaries newsletter: our free short film email
item.description: Be the first to see our latest thought-provoking films, bringing you bold and original storytelling from around the world
